item.title: Book Review: Learning PHP, MySQL, and JavaScript: A Step-By-Step Guide to Creating Dynamic Websites (Animal Guide)
item.description:
Note: This post was created awhile back on another platform and I migrated to my current one.

Note I’ve matured now and have decided to not post any books I do not like. I apologize in advance for my negative review of this book and I did not intend to be overly negative. I was young and am still learning.

The post:

Learning PHP, MySQL, and JavaScript

A Step-By-Step Guide to Creating Dynamic Websites (Animal Guide)

My Review

I needed to review PHP since many things have changed. I first tried Head First PHP & MySQL, but it wasn‚Äôt technical enough for me. While I initially thought its teaching style would help, it didn‚Äôt work out.

This book assumes some programming knowledge, which is great because it moves at a faster pace. Unlike Head First PHP & MySQL, which is slow, this book goes straight to the key subjects‚ÄîPHP, MySQL, and even touches on other topics. However, when I reached the JavaScript section, I stopped reading.

Pros & Cons

‚úÖ What I Liked

  • Fast-paced if you already know some programming.
  • Great MySQL chapters ‚Äì I learned about MySQL database engines like InnoDB and ISAM and how to search databases like a search engine.
  • Good for PHP basics ‚Äì helped me dive back into PHP and solidify the fundamentals of PHP5.

‚ùå What I Didn’t Like

  • Too many code errors ‚Äì you can find them listed here.
  • Confusing examples ‚Äì Some techniques shouldn’t even be used in real-world applications.
  • PHP authentication example is flawed ‚Äì The book combines HTTP authentication with PHP sessions, but doesn’t explain how to log out properly. Deleting browser cookies doesn‚Äôt work, and I had to Google better solutions (hint: use a logout flag in the script).
  • Smarty introduction is weak ‚Äì Installation instructions were unclear, which is why I wrote a separate guide for Windows XP.
  • No Object-Oriented PHP ‚Äì All PHP examples are procedural, with no coverage of OOP in PHP5.
  • Terrible JavaScript section ‚Äì The JavaScript coding style is ugly, doesn‚Äôt follow best practices, and lacks proper variable declarations (var variable1) and semicolons. A better beginner JavaScript book would be a wiser choice (I’ll post a review of one soon).

Final Verdict

This book is a basic introduction to PHP for those with a programming background. However, it does not cover Object-Oriented PHP5 at all.

I‚Äôd rate it ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è (3/5 stars) because it helped me refresh my PHP knowledge, but I wouldn‚Äôt recommend buying it‚Äîespecially if you‚Äôre looking for advanced topics or modern best practices.

üìå Warning: I only read up to Chapter 16 (out of 20). I stopped when I reached JavaScript.

Oh, and if you click the image and buy it from Amazon, I get some store credit for more books‚Äîbut honestly, this isn‚Äôt worth buying. üòâ
